verses.verse: And she said to her, “All that you say to me I will do.”
So she went down to the threshing floor and did according to all that her mother-in-law instructed her.

And after Boaz had eaten and drunk, and (Judg. 19:6, 9, 22; 2 Sam. 13:28; Esth. 1:10) his heart was cheerful, he went to lie down at the end of the heap of grain; and she came softly, uncovered his feet, and lay down.
Now it happened at midnight that the man was startled, and turned himself; and there, a woman was lying at his feet.
And he said, “Who are you?” So she answered, “I am Ruth, your maidservant. (Ezek. 16:8) Take your maidservant under your wing, for you are (Ruth 2:20; 3:12) a close relative.”

Then he said, (Ruth 2:20) “Blessed are you of the LORD, my daughter! For you have shown more kindness at the end than (Ruth 1:8) at the beginning, in that you did not go after young men, whether poor or rich.
And now, my daughter, do not fear. I will do for you all that you request, for all the people of my town know that you are a virtuous woman.
Now it is true that I am a (Prov. 12:4; 31:10-31) close relative; however, (Ruth 3:9) there is a relative closer than I.

Stay this night, and in the morning it shall be that if he will (Ruth 4:1) perform the duty of a close relative for you—good; let him do it. But if he does not want to perform the duty for you, then I will perform the duty for you, (Deut. 25:5-10; Ruth 4:5, 10; Matt. 22:24) as the LORD lives! Lie down until morning.”

So she lay at his feet until morning, and she arose before one could recognize another. Then he said, (Judg. 8:19; Jer. 4:2; 12:16) “Do not let it be known that the woman came to the threshing floor.”
Also he said, “Bring the shawl that is on you and hold it.” And when she held it, he measured six ephahs of barley, and laid it on her. Then she went into the city.
When she came to her mother-in-law, she said, “Is that you, my daughter?” Then she told her all that the man had done for her.
And she said, “These six ephahs of barley he gave me; for he said to me, ‘Do not go empty-handed to your mother-in-law.’ ”

Then she said, ((Rom. 12:17; 14:16; 1 Cor. 10:32; 2 Cor. 8:21; 1 Thess. 5:22)) “Sit still, my daughter, until you know how the matter will turn out; for the man will not rest until he has concluded the matter this day.”

(Boaz Redeems Ruth) Now Boaz went up to the gate and sat down there; and behold, ((Ps. 37:3, 5)) the close relative of whom Boaz had spoken came by. So Boaz said, “Come aside, friend, sit down here.” So he came aside and sat down.
And he took ten men of (Ruth 3:12) the elders of the city, and said, “Sit down here.” So they sat down.
Then he said to the close relative, “Naomi, who has come back from the country of Moab, sold the piece of land (1 Kin. 21:8; Prov. 31:23) which belonged to our brother Elimelech.

And I thought to inform you, saying, (Lev. 25:25) ‘Buy it back (Jer. 32:7, 8) in the presence of the inhabitants and the elders of my people. If you will redeem it, redeem it; but if you will not redeem it, then tell me, that I may know; (Gen. 23:18) for there is no one but you to redeem it, and I am next after you.’ ” And he said, “I will redeem it.”

Then Boaz said, “On the day you buy the field from the hand of Naomi, you must also buy it from Ruth the Moabitess, the wife of the dead, (Lev. 25:25) to perpetuate the name of the dead through his inheritance.”

(Gen. 38:8; Deut. 25:5, 6; Ruth 3:13; Matt. 22:24) And the close relative said, “I cannot redeem it for myself, lest I ruin my own inheritance. You redeem my right of redemption for yourself, for I cannot redeem it.”

(Ruth 3:12, 13; Job 19:14) Now this was the custom in former times in Israel concerning redeeming and exchanging, to confirm anything: one man took off his sandal and gave it to the other, and this was a confirmation in Israel.
Therefore the close relative said to Boaz, “Buy it for yourself.” So he took off his sandal.
